content_html:
If I wanted to add colors to SEM pictures how would I do it? Let’s also add the stipulation that I don’t have access to PhotoShop or anything that would cost money. Illegal downloading isn’t an option. This has been on my mind for quite some time, but yesterday I sat down after dinner and developed my solution. This is my logic through the process.

  1. I need a way to analyze the RGB of every pixel in an image.
  2. I need to develop a simple algorithm to manipulate the RGB for every pixel.
  3. Apply the algorithm and generate the colored picture.

RGB is the value for Red, Green, and Blue coded for each pixel. They run from 0 to 255. So, I wrote a script that will analyze this pixel information using php. My canvas was Yow et al.‘s recent image of colloidosomes, shown below.

A gray scale picture will have the same value for RGB. The simplest manipulations will be to hold either R, G, or B to zero and let the others retain their original value. This yields teal for R=0, violet for G=0, and yellow for B=0.

To generate blue (R=0, G=0), green (R=0, B=0), and red (G=0, B=0) you’ll need to set two values to zero.

Primary colors are nice, but if you want to have softer gentler colors you’ll need to apply an algorithm to your RGBs. For a light blue, I use the following R=(0.2 * B), G=(0.6 * B), B=B.

An orange I like is R=R, G= (0.5 * R), B=0.

If someone knows a simpler way of SEM color manipulation please share. Also, if someone would like me to make a script where you can upload your SEM image and apply a single color filter let me know.

Mitch
html:

Adding colors to SEM images

December 11, 2008 •By mitch •In fun

If I wanted to add colors to SEM pictures how would I do it? Let’s also add the stipulation that I don’t have access to PhotoShop or anything that would cost money. Illegal downloading isn’t an option. This has been on my mind for quite some time, but yesterday I sat down after dinner and developed my solution. This is my logic through the process.

  1. I need a way to analyze the RGB of every pixel in an image.
  2. I need to develop a simple algorithm to manipulate the RGB for every pixel.
  3. Apply the algorithm and generate the colored picture.

RGB is the value for Red, Green, and Blue coded for each pixel. They run from 0 to 255. So, I wrote a script that will analyze this pixel information using php. My canvas was Yow et al.‘s recent image of colloidosomes, shown below.

A gray scale picture will have the same value for RGB. The simplest manipulations will be to hold either R, G, or B to zero and let the others retain their original value. This yields teal for R=0, violet for G=0, and yellow for B=0.

To generate blue (R=0, G=0), green (R=0, B=0), and red (G=0, B=0) you’ll need to set two values to zero.

Primary colors are nice, but if you want to have softer gentler colors you’ll need to apply an algorithm to your RGBs. For a light blue, I use the following R=(0.2 * B), G=(0.6 * B), B=B.

An orange I like is R=R, G= (0.5 * R), B=0.

If someone knows a simpler way of SEM color manipulation please share. Also, if someone would like me to make a script where you can upload your SEM image and apply a single color filter let me know.

Mitch


Tags: Alexander Routh•colloidosome•Huai Yow•Langmuir•SEM

19 Comments

  1. sam says:
    On December 11, 2008 @ 4:44 pm

    ImageJ (http://rsb.info.nih.gov/ij/) is a nice, free, powerful software for images and movies (“stacks”).

    • mitch says:
      On December 11, 2008 @ 10:36 pm

      I downloaded the program, but I can’t figure out how to color it. Any suggestions?

  2. Bobby says:
    On December 11, 2008 @ 7:18 pm

    Another free image editor is Paint.Net (www.getpaint.net; Windows only). I have no idea if this is what you want.

  3. solidasarock says:
    On December 11, 2008 @ 8:34 pm

    How would you have multiple colors then? Could you develop something with your script for certain areas, or is the image still going to be monochromatic? I remember all those SEM images of flies with different pictures. I’m going to have to find out how those were made.

    • mitch says:
      On December 11, 2008 @ 10:29 pm

      Definitely, I can program which regions I want certain colors. From just playing with this for a day or so, I really feel I have a good handle on image manipulation. However, I suspect it would take longer to program than it would to learn how to apply similar effects with photoshop or some other program.

      I could not write a user script that would allow someone that much functionality, just the basic one color manipulation.

      • Brad VanMiddlesworth says:
        On December 12, 2008 @ 12:15 am

        Mitch,

        If you take a look at Python, within the SciPy module there is the ndImage submodule. The label function can grab regions, which can be given a particular RGB weight function, then put back into the image.

        I can write up a test script for you next week, after I finish grading.
        Brad

        • mitch says:
          On December 12, 2008 @ 2:18 pm

          Thanks, php has similar modules too. They’re probably rather equivalent except python should work faster.

        • Brad VanMiddlesworth says:
          On December 12, 2008 @ 7:25 pm

          I don’t know the php language, but on a purely entertainment project such as this, efficiency is the least of my worries.

          The benefit of the SciPy module is that it’s coded in C, and therefore is about as fast as it could be, assembly code withstanding. This is what I use for my home-built data analysis software for image processing.

          Send me an email (I assume you can see mine on this site) if you would like me to set up a test script. Since we’re between semesters I don’t mind taking a bit of time for fun.
          Brad

  4. Brad VanMiddlesworth says:
    On December 11, 2008 @ 9:32 pm

    To do certain areas you could do a gradient matrix of the image for image segmentation then apply random weight values of the RGB values for given areas.

    Mind you this would probably look like tie-dye. But let’s face it, this is all for fun anyway, as any image processing must be done by luminance of a greyscale.

    Brad V

  5. Phil says:
    On December 12, 2008 @ 2:32 am

    Another powerful free image manipulation program is The Gimp (http://www.gimp.org/).

    • Will says:
      On December 12, 2008 @ 7:59 pm

      When I read the first few lines, I was going to suggest GIMP as well. (GNU Image Manipulation Program)

      I’m very impressed; I think I’ll try doing something similar next week.

    • mitch says:
      On December 13, 2008 @ 4:36 pm

      I played with GIMP today and it seems to work adequately. But, I feel like I have so much more power in php, I literally can set the color of any pixel I want and do it pixel-by-pixel.

      The quality of the image when I used a code based solution versus software was also very apparent. The images I made in php seem significantly more vibrant and intense than their GIMP counterparts. But, I likely just need more practice with it.

      • ChemE says:
        On December 21, 2008 @ 9:10 pm

        Sometimes it’s better to know how to use one tool really well then several tools to a limited extent. That said, people who do high level math in Excel kill me.

  6. Paul says:
    On December 14, 2008 @ 4:49 pm

    Have a look at software developed by CSIRO and commercialised by a company called Dindima. They use two SEMs of the same object and use some clever algorithms (that I don’t remotely understand) to produce breathtaking colour SEMs. Check out these examples: http://www.dindima.com/spectrumEgPictures.php

    And it’s not just to make pretty pictures – the colourisation of SEMs adds a depth perception that allows better analysis of the images for the human eye.

  7. Enahs says:
    On December 14, 2008 @ 9:04 pm

    It is trivial in PhotoShop. And GIMP is a free version of Photoshop, it has been years since I used GIMP, but it could do this years ago. Sorry about such a delay in noticing the post, been busy.

    Open the image in GIMP/Photoshop.
    Create a new layer.
    Fill that layer with the midtone of the base color you want.
    Set the layer blending mode to Overlay (there are other modes that will give cool effects as well).
    Play around with the opacity and fill sliders to fine adjust.
    You are not limited to on color, you can easily create patterns and such to.

    Here are two I made in like 25 seconds, no lie. One is just colored, and the other is a Christmas tree ball ornament inspired SEM!
    http://www.ualr.edu/szsullivan/images/c1%20color.jpg
    http://www.ualr.edu/szsullivan/images/christmas%20sem.jpg

    As for not looking good in the end, it all has to do with how you save and if you save with any kind of compression or attempts to reduce file size.

    • mitch says:
      On December 14, 2008 @ 10:40 pm

      The thing is, I’ve learned what your intrinsically doing. Just looking at your image I can generate the algorithm you used in my head. For instance in my image of the green collidosome, I made whites look like greens and slowly go to blacks. Where in your first image you make whites look like white, transition to greens, and then blacks.

      I can do this in code by making grays less than 128 follow this equation: R = $avg * 0.0, G = $avg * 0.0 + 20, B = $avg * 0.0

      For gray’s >128 but <240 : R = 20 + ($avg - 128) * 2, G = 20 + $avg * 1.0, B = 20 + ($avg - 128) * 2

      Finally for gray's >240 : R = ($avg – 128) * 2, G = $avg * 1.0, B =($avg – 128) * 2

      The resultant image is here:
      http://www.chemistry-blog.com/geenmitch.png

      As you can see it is quite close, but not exactly what you ended up with. Likely there is a second order perturbation the program used, which I can take into account but for simplicity I’m ignoring it.

      So after all this how can I ever use a program, I just get it now.

  8. Enahs says:
    On December 15, 2008 @ 7:13 am

    But you are doing the most simple operation in image editing on computers. It is actually more complicated to resize an image than change the RGB values (though I have no doubt there are libraries with that function already available). The advantage of using Photoshop/GIMP is you can visually see what is happening, and easily make small and minor changes. And fine tune the image to how you would like.

    The actual method you are doing without mixing the RGB, you can do in Photoshop by hitting CTRL 1-3 to turn on and off the individual RGB channels.

    Photoshop/GIMP can be used as “look, pretty colors”. But they are advanced enough to go deeper and you really have to understand what is going on to really use well.

    I am not trying to insult your accomplishment. You for sure went about it in a more scientific manner, and it is something to be proud of.
    But you asked if anybody knows an easier way. I do! 🙂
    It took me 5 seconds (literally) to make this image:
    http://www.ualr.edu/szsullivan/images/mitch%20sem.jpg
    It took longer to find the picture of you to use!

    🙂

    • mitch says:
      On December 15, 2008 @ 9:37 am

      Fair enough, but I’m going to bug you with a lot of questions now. 🙂

  9. Ali says:
    On December 18, 2008 @ 10:31 am

    If you want something quick from the command line, try ImageMagick:

    http://www.imagemagick.org/Usage/color/

    There are also a couple of PHP interfaces, mentioned on the home page:

    http://www.imagemagick.org/script/index.php

content:
If I wanted to add colors to SEM pictures how would I do it? Let’s also add the stipulation that I don’t have access to PhotoShop or anything that would cost money. Illegal downloading isn’t an option. This has been on my mind for quite some time, but yesterday I sat down after dinner and developed my solution. This is my logic through the process.  
 
 I need a way to analyze the RGB of every pixel in an image.  
 I need to develop a simple algorithm to manipulate the RGB for every pixel.  
 Apply the algorithm and generate the colored picture.  
  
 RGB is the value for  Red  ,  Green   , and  Blue   coded for each pixel. They run from  0   to  255  . So, I wrote a script that will analyze this pixel information using php. My canvas was  Yow   et al   .  ‘s recent image of colloidosomes, shown below.  
   
 A gray scale picture will have the same value for RGB. The simplest manipulations will be to hold either R, G, or B to  zero   and let the others retain their original value. This yields  teal   for R= 0  ,  violet   for G= 0  , and  yellow    for B= 0  .  
     
 To generate  blue   (R= 0  , G= 0  ),  green   (R= 0  , B= 0  ), and  red   (G= 0  , B= 0  ) you’ll need to set two values to  zero  .  
     
 Primary colors are nice, but if you want to have softer gentler colors you’ll need to apply an algorithm to your RGBs. For a  light blue  , I use the following R=( 0.2   * B), G=( 0.6   * B), B=B.  
   
 An  orange   I like is R=R, G= ( 0.5   * R), B= 0.   
   
 If someone knows a simpler way of SEM color manipulation please share. Also, if someone would like me to make a script where you can upload your SEM image and apply a single color filter let me know.  
 Mitch
